Create an eco-friendly website ‚Äî another reason to keep it static as much as possible ‚Äì your website won‚Äôt cause as much harm to the environment (although no website‚Äôs an even better option).

From an environmental perspective, a well-built static site is far kinder to the end device it is rendered on. The server has to do far less work to serve up your average static site. Devices with rechargeable batteries (laptops, tablets, smartphones, etc.) will use more energy to render resource-intensive websites, as they require more work to stitch everything together. Less energy expenditure means less frequent recharge times.

I have an absurdly complicated microblog/website set up, but it‚Äôs all possible with microblog.

  1. Post to microblog
  2. When My site builds, grab all the posts from the microblog json feed and put them in a Jekyll data object
  3. Create posts from each item in the data object
  4. Publish each microblog post on my site
  5. Create a robots.txt file in a custom microblog theme so search engines don‚Äôt index it

And done.
items.content_text:
I have an absurdly complicated microblog/website set up, but it‚Äôs all possible with microblog.

1. Post to microblog
2. When My site builds, grab all the posts from the microblog json feed and put them in a Jekyll data object
3. Create posts from each item in the data object
4. [Publish each microblog post on my site](https://www.thisdaysportion.com/microblog)
5. Create a `robots.txt` file in a custom microblog theme so search engines don‚Äôt index it

And done.
